The first thing I wanted to sayâ€¦
Ken had nothing to do with it.

Oh, well, I wanted to emphatically agree with Tyler in that I got to many more people who'd never vote for a Clinton than folks who'd never vote for a black guy.
So that's the first thing I wanted to say.
And the second thing was that I'm a Chicago Obama supporter who is one of the 13,000 volunteers who went down to South Carolina last weekend.
And I think that Obama's success was in large part due to grassroots support.
In fact, there is one volunteer for every 23 voters, I think, doing get-out-to-vote activities.
So, 75,000 volunteers are now poised to help Obama on Tuesday.
But what I'd like to know is if you think it's possible for a candidate to successfully run a grassroots campaign in 22 states at once.
It makes it awfully difficult.
Or is Super Tuesday going to be all about TV ads and polls and spin like that Thompson-Edwards kind of thing that they have right now?
And more about free media if you can land in an airport and get coverage on the local news.
Isn't that a big deal on these big primary days, Ken?
Yeah.
Well, Kristen's alternative - choices here - I suspect the latter is going to happen.
I mean, obviously, in the states like Iowa and New Hampshire, you have time, you have plenty of media attention.
But you also have time not to be distracted by 21 other states voting at the same time.
And you can go into people's living rooms and talk about issues.
Unfortunately, with the way Super Tuesday is arranged, it really disenfranchises 90 percent of the electorate because nobody sees the candidates up close.
And by that, what you're doing really is just watching TV ads and, again, watching the spin on the 6 o'clock news.
But you know something?
We've never seen anything like this before.
And you know, we've been wrong in so many predictions.
I'd love to see something like a grassroots operation for any candidate make a difference in such a giant national primary-like thing like Super Tuesday.
And Kristen, thanks very much for the call.
We appreciate it.
Thank you.
Bye-bye.
And Ken, we have before Super Tuesday, a number of events beginning tonight with the Republican debate.
Then there's a Democratic debate tomorrow night.
Right.

I think the last Republican debate, they were pretty much civil.

You don't know what's going to come out of that, too.
And it'll be very interesting to see what comes with the Democrats, too, without John Edwards, one on one.

And of course, Mike Gravel is not going to be in that debate.
It's really between Obama and Clinton.
It will be very interesting to see what happens there, too.
And as close to a national primary as we have ever had, there's no experience with this.
There's no way to know what to expect.
No, on February 5th, there's going to be more than 50 percent of the Democratic delegates at stake to win the nomination - just under 50 percent for the Republicans.
You know, whatever we think is the frontrunner, whatever we think is the lay of the land going into February 5th, for all we know, it could completely turn around on that day.

We're going to be there on Super Tuesday plus one on Wednesday on Political Junkie day.
But Ken, if you wanted to name a couple of states where people should really look out and see what's going on in the polls, what would they be?

It's a special kind of horror to be delayed for, let's say, even half an hour or even five minutes, for that matter, in a subway car that's stalled that has no electricity that's well underneath the ground and the air is stifling.
And that - just the fear of that happening is enough to drive people away, isn't it?
Well, certainly, like the - we talked about California, which, of course, has the most delegates, and certainly on the Republican side as well, Democratic side.
But one thing people should know, on every - in every Democratic contest, it's proportional.
There's no such thing as a winner-take-all on the Democratic side.
It's proportional.
You get X amount of percentage in the state or congressional delegate district.
You get that percent of the delegates, not so on the Republican side.
While it's proportional in California for the Republicans, New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are winner-take-all.
So theoretically, with John - with Rudy Giuliani out of the race and perhaps expecting to endorse John McCain, McCain could win New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
Winner-take-all, that's a lot of delegates, so watch those states as well.
Ken will be back with us a week from today on that NPR News special.
Ken Rudin, as always, thanks very much.
Thanks, Neal.
Ken Rudin also writes the Political Junkie column, which you can see at npr.org.
I'm Neal Conan.
This is TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
Joining the U.S.
Army is a goal of many young adults, including several hundred who, as children, were brought to this country illegally.
The Trump administration is considering eliminating or scaling back two programs that put them on the path to the military.
NPR's Richard Gonzales introduces us to two young men, both hoping to make it to basic training before it's too late.
Harminder Saini was 6 years old when his parents brought him to the United States from India.
The now 20-year-old college history major grew up in Queens, N.Y.
All these times, you know, growing up doing American things, you know, like celebrating Halloween, or going to the park or - it was just things - everything was normal.
Like any American teenager, he hoped to earn some extra cash with his first job.
So he asked his parents for his Social Security number.
That's when they told him he was in this country illegally, so he didn't have one.
It was like, wait, so I'm not American.
So it was very frustrating, disappointing and also confusing.
On the other side of the country in Southern California, 20-year-old John Sena had an almost parallel experience.
His parents brought him to this country when he was 10 from the Philippines.
He grew up near a Marine recruiting center.
Ever since I was 12, I saw the Marines in their dress blues, and I thought I always wanted to be a Marine.
But when he tried to enlist, his parents told him he couldn't.
My mom just kind of broke the silence, said, oh, we're not supposed to be here.
We don't have any papers.
Both Harminder Saini and John Sena enrolled in DACA, the Obama-era program called Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals.
It protected them against deportation and came with a work permit.
It also allowed them to enlist in the Army under a program called MAVNI - Military Accessions Vital to the National Interest.
MAVNI accepts noncitizens in the health care professions or with foreign language skills and offers a fast track to citizenship after basic training.
Saini speaks Punjabi.
Sena, a nursing student, speaks Tagalog.
They signed up for active duty in early 2016.
Here's Saini.
